subject: polity
title: Martial Law vs Suspension of Fundamental Rights

rows.martialLaw: **Military rule** replacing civil administration in a specific area due to breakdown of law and order
rows.suspensionFR: **Presidential order** under Art 359 suspending right to move court for enforcement of FRs during **National Emergency** (Art 352)

rows.martialLaw: **NO specific provision** in Constitution for Martial Law. **Art 34** only mentions indemnity for acts during Martial Law
rows.suspensionFR: **Art 359** - President can suspend right to move court for enforcement of FRs (except Art 20-21 after 44th Amendment)

rows.martialLaw: **Limited to specific area** where civil administration has broken down (local/regional)
rows.suspensionFR: **Applies to entire country** during National Emergency
**President** issues order under Art 359 on advice of Cabinet

rows.martialLaw: **Extra-constitutional** concept (borrowed from British tradition); based on common law
rows.suspensionFR: **Constitutional provision** - Art 359 explicitly provides for it

rows.martialLaw: **Military administration** replaces civil administration; Army takes over law and order
rows.suspensionFR: **Civil administration continues**; only enforcement of FRs suspended (people cannot move court)

rows.martialLaw: **Ordinary courts continue** to function; but **military courts** may be set up for summary trials
rows.suspensionFR: **Ordinary courts continue** but cannot entertain petitions for enforcement of suspended FRs

rows.martialLaw: FRs **NOT automatically suspended**; but **may not be enforceable** in practice due to military control
rows.suspensionFR: **Right to move court** for enforcement of FRs **explicitly suspended** by Presidential order (Art 20-21 cannot be suspended after 44th Amendment)

rows.martialLaw: **Till normalcy restored** in affected area; no fixed time limit
rows.suspensionFR: **Till Emergency continues**; cannot extend beyond Emergency period
**Emergency itself requires** Parliamentary approval every 6 months (Art 352)

rows.martialLaw: **Punjab (1919)** - After Jallianwala Bagh; **Bombay (1942)** - Quit India Movement. **Never declared in independent India**
rows.suspensionFR: **1975-77 Emergency** - President issued order under Art 359 suspending Art 14, 19, 21, 22 (ADM Jabalpur case: Even Art 21 suspended)

rows.martialLaw: **Art 34**: Parliament can indemnify persons for acts done during Martial Law (protect from legal action)
rows.suspensionFR: **Art 359(1A)** (added by 44th Amendment): Acts during Emergency NOT automatically protected; illegal acts still punishable

rows.martialLaw: Courts can review **after Martial Law ends**; examine if acts were justified
rows.suspensionFR: **During Emergency**: Cannot review (enforcement suspended). **After Emergency**: Can review legality of acts

rows.martialLaw: **Concept largely obsolete**; NOT declared in independent India; replaced by Armed Forces Special Powers Act (AFSPA) in disturbed areas
rows.suspensionFR: **44th Amendment (1978) safeguards**: Art 20-21 (life & liberty) **cannot be suspended** even during Emergency; procedural safeguards added

article34: **Article 34**: Restriction on rights conferred by Part III while Martial Law is in force
Parliament may **indemnify** any person for acts done in maintenance of law and order during Martial Law
Provides legal protection to military personnel for actions during Martial Law
NOT a provision to declare Martial Law; only deals with **consequences** of Martial Law
article359: **Article 359**: Suspension of enforcement of rights conferred by Part III during Emergency
**President can issue order** suspending right to move court for enforcement of FRs
**Art 359(1A)** (44th Amendment): Acts during Emergency NOT automatically protected; State must still act within law
**Applies only during National Emergency** (Art 352), not State or Financial Emergency
44thAmendment1978: **1. Art 20-21 cannot be suspended**: Right to life and liberty protected even during Emergency
**2. Art 359(1A) added**: Acts during Emergency not automatically indemnified; illegal acts still punishable
**3. Emergency in writing**: President's satisfaction must be communicated in writing with reasons
**4. Cabinet advice**: President must act on written advice of Cabinet (not alone)
**5. Limited grounds**: Emergency only for 'war, external aggression, armed rebellion' (removed 'internal disturbance')
**6. Judicial review restored**: Courts can examine if constitutional requirements met
admJabalpurCase: **ADM Jabalpur v Shivkant Shukla (1976)** - Darkest judgment in SC history
**During 1975 Emergency**, President suspended Art 21 under Art 359
**SC held (4:1)**: During Emergency when Art 21 suspended, **right to life itself suspended**; HC cannot be issued even for illegal detention
**Justice H.R. Khanna dissented**: Right to life cannot be suspended even during Emergency (he was superseded for this dissent)
**44th Amendment 1978**: Overruled this judgment; Art 20-21 **cannot be suspended** even during Emergency
**Lessons**: Led to constitutional safeguards; strengthened judicial independence
examTips: **Most asked**: Difference between Martial Law and Suspension of FRs
**Key difference**: Martial Law = Military rule (extra-constitutional); Suspension of FRs = Presidential order under Art 359 (constitutional)
**Art 34**: Indemnity for acts during Martial Law (NOT provision to declare it)
**Art 359**: Suspension of enforcement of FRs during Emergency
**44th Amendment**: Art 20-21 cannot be suspended; acts during Emergency not automatically protected
**ADM Jabalpur case**: Overruled by 44th Amendment; Art 21 cannot be suspended
**Remember**: Martial Law = Local, Military rule, Extra-constitutional; FR Suspension = National, Civil administration continues, Constitutional (Art 359)

data.summary: **Martial Law** = Military rule in specific area (extra-constitutional, Art 34 gives indemnity). **Suspension of FRs** = Presidential order under Art 359 during National Emergency (constitutional provision). **Key differences**: Martial Law is local, military rule, extra-constitutional; FR suspension is national, civil administration continues, constitutional. **44th Amendment 1978**: Art 20-21 cannot be suspended even during Emergency. **ADM Jabalpur (1976)**: Held Art 21 could be suspended (overruled by 44th Amendment). **Art 34** = Indemnity for Martial Law acts; **Art 359** = Suspension of FR enforcement during Emergency.
